fields.summary: Provide an HTTPS-by-default installation of the Console

status.description: The issue is considered finished, the resolution is correct. Issues which are closed can be reopened.

fields.description:
When Nginx is used as an SSL reverse-proxy in front of eucaconsole, this is not detected in the object details page when a link to the object is created and displayed.

I discovered this problem on one of the two systems created for Discover, which now have such Nginx reverse proxies in front of them with SSL certificates signed by the HP Cloud CA hierarchy, when I was testing a CFN template I uploaded to the "sample-templates" bucket.

The URL through which I reached the object is:
https://console.hp-aw2-1.hpcloudsvc.com/buckets/sample-templates/itemdetails/WordPress_Single_Instance_Eucalyptus.template

In the body of the page at this URL, there is an object Link with text:
https://objectstorage.hp-aw2-1.hpcloudsvc.com:8773/sample-templates/WordPress_Single_Instance_Eucalyptus.template
and value:
https://objectstorage.hp-aw2-1.hpcloudsvc.com:8773/sample-templates/WordPress_Single_Instance_Eucalyptus.template?Signature=HyovDqI8xuqgsbZiQpw%2BpU8lvzw%3D&Expires=1435038592&AWSAccessKeyId=AKIK7HVYG4NXSVATOI2A&x-amz-security-token=ZXVjYQAB6M%2BCLqwJZqbJBEadxrucK0J8G%2BZPsAadffinj0mxyI3L3LkoJ5piPzhletiXDtACW0vrMy22%2BuG0VRTOmuQicoXagw6ZfqAJZgY16ufRnWhO/RtWMW/EuQOWWmxhd5MXNPaVb0XJwCwRSuuio4xyBGfoXTT/0l7fD/lr/EvAH8a4EkmkdIHH01fUPmnmD4XXVYeux/ZL5W3L0DFJPT9G/E6KJP2HbxPVj29yn5adYBJ/XbDG7eK1hoA%3D

In both cases, the code correctly detects that https is in place (session.secure = true in console.ini), but does not detect that the reverse proxy is stripping off the ":8773" as it listens on the normal SSL port of 443

Expected behavior would be for the Links to be the same except with no port, and for them to work when clicked on, with the return path again going through the proxy.

It should be possible to detect if a proxy is in place by examination of the headers, as the proxy is setting Host and X-Forwarded-For.

Note this is running the version of the console used for the Discover demos, 
eucaconsole-4.1.1-0.0.6207.19.20150526git377827e.el6.noarch.rpm
fields.summary: Adjust S3 object links when HTTPS reverse proxy is present

comments.body:
David or Jenny - if you like, I can walk you through how I setup a newer variant of the reverse proxy logic which works with both UFS and the console, including SSL termination for both using 1 IP, on one of the systems created for Discover.

I think this problem exists with the prior console-only proxy variant I've seen documented before, and any solution would likely be the same for either reverse-proxy configuration, so I don't think such a walkthrough is required, but you might find it helpful. LMK if you're interested to schedule.

Hi [~mcrawford], we are currently working through 4.2 bugs in priority order, so this one might not make it in since it's minor. 

If that doesn't help or if the walkthrough would help for documenting the setup to get this to work, let me know.

[~jloza], I think I saw you confirmed the behavior, so you know what the effect is. 

My walkthrough would not change what you see, it was just to show you how I think (IMHO) my reverse-proxy method is an improvement over the prior method (supports both console and UFS on one IP, more standard method of using upstream and separate server config files seen where many virtual hosts are centralized into one set of proxies in a DMZ, etc.) So, unless you're curious, may not be relevant to this bug. I'd just want to test any fix against this when it does come out before it's closed.

The effect until this is fixed, is users can't successfully click on the links for S3 bucket objects, as those do include the https scheme, but don't strip off the unnecessary :8773 port. However, as a workaround, they can just copy and paste the link, removing the port manually, and I think this works even with the security token. And, any proxy access to the object via euca2ools S3 API or AWS CLI works. So, more of a usability hassle than a blocker.

Would be nice to have this fixed in 4.2.1 though...

[~jloza] and [~dkavanagh] Given that you've raised this to major, I will again offer to demo the newer method I've developed to use Nginx for SSL on both the Console and UFS on the same single Public IP address. If you plan on having this come out in 4.2 - and - this feature depends on some variant of Nginx proxy config to work properly, instead of a new configuration parameter in console.ini (i.e. canonical_domain or similar), I'd like to make sure my Nginx proxy config works with your solution, or I can adjust it to work.

I have this working on some systems in the PRC, or on both of the two systems we setup for Discover. LMK if you want to see a demo.
Thanks [~mcrawford], I think once one of us gets to working on this, we'll reach out.
[~mcrawford]: Could you paste or email me the nginx.conf you used to fix this issue?

[~kgill] I think a better approach is for me to work with you and make sure you can login to one of the PRC hosts where I've set this up, so you can look at every config file all working together, and see how the console and UFS virtual hosts co-exist.

Can you ping me on Lync, and I can work with you to make sure you can get into a couple of my PRC setups where this has been implemented, and I can show you where to look.

Also, I have shell scripts and manual procedure instructions on how to implement the reverse-proxy configuration, and the PKI infrastructure on which it depends, in my euca-demo project, on a branch I'm using to restructure, which can be found around this manual procedure:
https://github.com/eucalyptus/euca-demo/blob/feature/restructure/installs/install-10-faststart/docs/install-13-faststart-configure-proxy.md 

In that same docs directory are the other manual procedures you can run on top of faststart to add in the augmentations I usually add. In the ../bin directory are shell scripts which automate this, as long as you have the appropriate configuration file in the ../conf directory. 

I can walk you through that too if you want on a Lync screenshare, just let me know what works.

[~mcrawford]: Understood.  I'll need to investigate this today and will ping you by tomorrow.  There may be a simpler workaround we can implement in the console that won't require nginx config changes, which may be preferred since not all console installs can assumed to be behind an HTTPS proxy (at least not yet anyway).

Kamal,

Access

If you send me your normal username, UID, hashed password and ssh public key, I can create a user for you on the PRC systems, even the hosts used in the Discover demos, which contain the reverse-proxy and PKI infrastructure I have in place related to the S3 links ticket.

The logic to create a SHA-512 hashed version of your password, which is pretty safe to send around, is below.

password="your_password_here"
salt=$(openssl rand -hex 4)
python -c "import crypt, getpass, pwd; print crypt.crypt('$password', '\$6\$$salt\$')"

When I create an account for you, you can login as yourself with your private key, and sudo to root with the password used to create the hash.

These also have the default root password, if you’d rather get in that way.


You can reference either of these two systems:

odc-f-33, https://console.hp-gol01-f2.mjc.prc.eucalyptus-systems.com/ use: eucalyptus/admin/password
odc-f-34, https://console.hp-gol01-f3.mjc.prc.eucalyptus-systems.com/ use: eucalyptus/admin/password

These both have close to the latest eucaconsole RPM, with the new navbar, go through the reverse-proxy, and show the problem.

See these two manual procedures for a description of what I do related to setting up PKI and the reverse-proxy, which will also indicate where all key files you might want to look at are located.

https://github.com/eucalyptus/euca-demo/blob/feature/restructure/installs/install-10-faststart/docs/install-12-faststart-configure-pki.md
https://github.com/eucalyptus/euca-demo/blob/feature/restructure/installs/install-10-faststart/docs/install-13-faststart-configure-proxy.md

This also might be of interest - how I configure AWS CLI to go through the proxy:

https://github.com/eucalyptus/euca-demo/blob/feature/restructure/installs/install-10-faststart/docs/install-16-faststart-configure-awscli.md

if you want to run awscli or euca2ools, they are both setup to go through the reverse proxy with SSL.
- see /root/.euca/euca2ools.ini for euca2ools endpoings config, showing ssl use
- see /usr/lib/python2.6/site-packages/botocore/data/_endpoints.json.local.ssl for awscli endpoints config, showing ssl use

By default, when you login as root, you’re using the euca admin credentials, and can run either of these to illustrate:

euca-describe-keypairs
aws ec2 describe-key-pairs

Let me know if you want me to walk you through any of this via screen share.

Mike

Michael Crawford
Presales Technical Consultant
HP Helion Eucalyptus

mcrawford@hp.com<mailto:mcrawford@hp.com>
M +1 415-652-5483
O +1 650-258-5096
Hewlett-Packard Company

[cid:image001.png@01CF6887.B1D47C00]

[~kgill] Agreed. Whatever solution should work behind any variation of a reverse proxy, implemented with Nginx, Apache or even IIS or something else, using or not using HTTPS. 

They key is to know whatever the user is seeing in his browser's address bar and make links work off of that if different than what Eucalyptus thinks it's URL is, if possible to auto-discover this. Otherwise, some way to set an override "base" URL which is augmented with the PATH would be nice in complex scenarios where auto-discover is not possible or breaks.

I'd like to make sure this works with the existing Nginx proxy instructions I obtained from Lester in the Cloud Administrator course which only handles the console, as well as my Nginx proxy which handles both the console and UFS with a custom PKI infrastrcture as well as external CAs. 

I just sent you an email with all you should need to get into a couple of my PRC hosts which have this newer reverse-proxy setup. Let me know how I can help when you're ready.

[~mcrawford]: Hmm, I'm unable to reproduce this on my local setup with nginx and the console configured for HTTPS.  The S3 object URL contains port 8773 (as shown in the screenshot), and the download works just fine.  I'm going to dig into your setup to investigate.

Go here (credentials in email): odc-f-33, https://console.hp-gol01-f2.mjc.prc.eucalyptus-systems.com/ to check.

One note: I hope to be able to "lock down" the CLC in the future so that only ports 53, 80 and 443 are open to the world, and only the DNS logic and Nginx are exposed to possible external attack. I think Nginx is a much better vetted program from a security perspective than anything we could write, just due to resource constraints, so it's less likely to contain unknown security exploits. This means that if we're going through a proxy, that all links must also go through the same proxy. So, even if the https + :8773 variant works for you, that's not the correct path, and it really should not work - it can't be going through the proxy, as the proxy is not listening on that port. It would switch from using the proxy's SSL cert to the self-signed inside the java code.

[~mcrawford]: I pointed my local HTTPS nginx/console setup to ufshost = hp-gol01-f2.mjc.prc.eucalyptus-systems.com and was able to download an S3 object just fine (screenshot attached), so I suspect something must be wrong with the nginx setup on your PRC host.

[~mcrawford]: I understand your points w.r.t. locking down the ports.  I wonder if the correct solution here is to set force_http=True in boto's generate_url() method for S3 objects?  I'll try that in a branch and will keep you posted.

[~kgill] Note I have not yet locked down port 8773 on those PRC hosts. In my experience designing and implementing websites which have often needed PCI compliance, I wind up with a dedicated reverse-proxy which runs directly on the app server providing a service, associated with a private IP address via split-brain DNS for internal users, as well as a shared reverse-proxy setup on a farm of web/proxy servers running in a DMZ, associated with a public DNS for external users. The external proxies are the focus of most security efforts, including the firewalls which exists between the internet and the DMZ, and the DMZ and internal networks. We usually want to limit what gets into the external firewall, software firewall running on the DMZ-based external proxy and the internal firewall, to only 80 and 443, so we're sure all traffic can only enter and leave via this proxy via paths known by the firewalls, which are usually scanning the traffic on those known ports for attacks.

If we are to create clouds which can be exposed to the internet yet pass a security audit for larger corporations that have seen what's been happening with hackers lately, I think we MUST support this type of DMZ-based reverse proxy so our servers do not have to be placed in the DMZ. This is PCI 101 - the most basic requirement.  This means that any URLs we display on pages should be proxy-aware. I'm just removing the port because my proxy listens on the standard port. But, Nginx allows for much more sophisticated url rewriting during the proxy - it would be nice to at least allow for removal of the port, but ideally the code would look at the HTTP request headers, which will include proxy headers that show the URL with which the user reached the proxy, so that it can use that to construct self-referential URLs which again will work through the proxy. If there's another method, all ears. I'm OK with a console.ini value which allows the user to override the base URL so you just prepend that to whatever PATH value you want, if auto-discovery of this via headers is difficult.

On your last point, I don't know boto well enough to know how that might work. It seems like you're saying you're using boto's generate_url() function to construct the URL for the S3 link, which you don't modify further. Seems like that flag would change the generated URL to start with http://... but not do anything about the :8773 port, which is moving in the opposite direction of correct behavior to me.

If there's some way to indicate that UFS is running on a port other than 8773, so boto returns an URL which does not include the :port when http and 80 or https and 443, that might work. But, I think that if there's some way to do what I suggested above, lookup, or have as a config parameter, the URL's "scheme:://domain/" prefix for self-referential URLs, that would always result in correct behavior, regardless of proxy.

One last point. I've assumed that to minimize the risk of the proxy causing problems, I wanted to allow for all "inter-Euca" communication to occur on normal ports, oblivious to the proxy. It's only external users that may go through this, either on a DMZ, or on a co-resident proxy on the CLC itself, both for API and console. This allows me to use firewall rules on hardware or software (iptables) to restrict all subnets except Euca's own public/management/private subnets to only go through the proxy. I wouldn't want to lose this concept with any solution. There should just be a method to have self-referential URLs use the same prefix as the user did when reaching the console via the proxy - this should not, ideally, change how the console obtains it's information from UFS or directly from the CLC - that communication path should NOT go through the proxy, as it introduces non-predictable and untested behavior - we can't test all the proxy configs companies may want to use.

[~mcrawford]: Initial testing with generate_url(force_http=True) seems to work, but it sounds as though we shouldn't pursue that path since what we need here is to remove the :8773 part in generated URLs, which I'll try next.
[~mcrawford]: Removing the :8773 from the object URL generated via boto's item.generate_url() method doesn't work in my initial testing, so the port seems to be required.

Are the UFS endpoints being exposed to the outside world through the reverse proxy? If so, it sounds like it's stripping the port and using 443? I mean, we should use SSL for UFS API calls. Why doesn't the console simply talk to the UFS endpoints through the reverse proxy in this case? I know it's another hop, but that hop probably isn't going to be where a lot of the time is taken up. We could do some performance testing, but I think if the console (which is really just using client APIs) needs to communicate URLs (like for S3 objects) to the outside world, we should talk through the same endpoints URLs as the outside world.
The other option is to configure a special endpoint (which is the reverse proxy) just for generating these urls, since the generation doesn't actually call the url, it just does a computation.

[~dkavanagh] Doctor's appt this morning, why I can't make 10am meeting Kamal proposed.

I can comment more on this when I get back, but yet, the purpose of the reverse proxy is to add termination of both console and UFS for external users. It's easier to configure and more efficient, when we configure SSL on a reverse proxy in front of Java applications, in my experience. C-code speed, simpler. shared config with rest of OS. Java SSL sucks too.

I'm hesitant to have the console go through a relatively new and untested component, in that I think all Euca components are tested most with direct connections, the proxy config - for it to be most flexible for actual large client scenarios - needs to be flexible to handle what may be existing reverse-proxy setups which we leverage, meaning we can't always specify our own, so this introduces a bit of risk.

But, that said, if the easiest way to have the console's self-referential URLs correctly represent the proxy base url is to do this, I can see that if we consider the console as just an add-on tool which puts a GUI in front of the API, then having it hit the API via the same via-proxy method as we're setting things up for the clients to access, could make sense.

Can discuss more later when I'm back, somewhere around 10:30 or 11:00

[~dkavanagh]: Just to clarify, with the console's default nginx.conf the generated S3 URLs do *not* strip off the :8773 part, so the pattern for the generated object download URL is https://UFS_HOST:8773/services/objectstorage/BUCKET_NAME/... , which works but isn't desirable.

Using 'force_http=True' in boto's generate_url() strips off the 8773 port, which returns a broken link, and manually stripping off the 8773 (but leaving the https part) doesn't work either in my initial testing.
If you look at the signing method, host/port and the rest are all included in the computation, so modifying the link after is no bueno.

[~dkavanagh] and [~kgill]: the host and port are never part of the signature in AWS S3 V2 signing (that changes with V4 but we don't support v4 just yet). See: http://docs.aws.amazon.com/AmazonS3/latest/dev/RESTAuthentication.html
ok, I thought we'd switched for all of the services.

[~zhill] However we handle this now, if v4 signatures must include the full URL, we should make sure there's a way to implement an SSL-terminating reverse proxy in front of UFS which works with v4 sigs when that comes out.

I think if we've decided that the best way to do this is to use Nginx in front of the console, I'd argue for using this same method in front of UFS too, instead of modifications to the java keystore. 

I think the Nginx using OpenSSL method is superior in many ways.
* It can run directly on the CLC and/or on separate reverse proxy hardware in a DMZ for security-sensitive scenarios.
* It handles SSL encryption logic in OpenSSL C code, better performance.
* Nginx or Apache have long-term SNI support, allowing both console and UFS to run with SSL on the same single public IP.
* Nginx is almost certainly been through, and continues to go through, more widespread and constant security audits, so making that the termination point for what may be Internet users is going to be more secure than having Internet users directly hit the CLC
* Building on first point, having the ability to setup an SSL-terminating reverse proxy in a DMZ, separate from where Euca runs, means we can keep Euca behind additional "interior" corporate firewalls which usually exist between DMZ networks and internal networks. This is a requirement for PCI certification (no direct connections from the Internet to app servers).
* Am I the only one that thinks we should be able to expose "normal" http and https URLs which run on the standard ports and therefore do not require ports in the URL? I just do not see URLs with ports visible in them in other software. This technique makes that possible.
* It's possible to split out all UFS to separate hosts or combine them for larger configurations without having to worry about secondary IPs, as long as we use wildcard SSL certs, everything works with one public IP on each host.

btw, http://docs.aws.amazon.com/general/latest/gr/signature-version-2.html
It shows the endpoint being part of the signing.

[~zhill], [~dkavanagh] - David, per your last comment - if you haven't seen what I do to make AWS CLI work with Euca, I thought I'd show it here (see: [^_endpoints.json]), as I think that will make more clear what I mean as far as the benefits we get by moving Euca towards (at least) standardized (I'd make them mandatory) endpoints which:
# Use the endpoint format: {noformat}{scheme}://{service}.{region}.{domain}{noformat}
 (i.e. [https://console.hp-aw2-1.hpcloudsvc.com], [https://cloudformation.hp-gol01-f1.mjc.prc.eucalyptus-systems.com])
# Use the standard AWS service names, or at least give me a configuration parameter that lets me use [https://ec2.hp-aw2-1.hpcloudsvc.com] instead of or in addition to [https://console.hp-aw2-1.hpcloudsvc.com]
# Includes the region code, which is a top-level cloud property, not something I can't change from "eucalyptus" at the top level (as returned by euca-describe-regions), but I can change with cloudformation.region lower down. If cloudformation and v2 signatures are going to require this, it seems like a fundamental property of the cloud which should be set, and it unchangeable, during initialization.
# Has a parent domain, which ideally is consistent across all future federated clouds, so a single entry in the _endpoints.json file handles all of them.

If you look at that _endpoints.json file, you can see how they have this default logic at the top which handles all but exceptions, so if we used AWS service names, I would not have to define the exceptions you see for ec2, elasticloadbalancing, monitoring, swf, and some of sts further down. 

And, it should be clear that, just like I'm able to use one additional set of json snippets for both Discover systems (and more) as long as they all use hpcloudsvc.com as the parent domain, or another set to support all my PRC-based demo/test regions, trying to conform to AWS endpoint standard URLs means we can configure awscli or other botocore-based code with fewer additions.

I just think the closer we hew, the fewer "gotchas" we're going to hit as we continue to chase what AWS is doing in the future.

More than anything - I just don't want to start setting up all these cool tweaks to get things like a reverse proxy or awscli to work, only to have 4.2+ break them - because you weren't aware of them. So, this is my attempt to "sell" you on the value of these...

[~dkavanagh], yes that is for the 'Query' APIs like EC2. S3 has a different signature method because the service heavily uses redirects due to the global namespace and DNS support for bucket names. S3 is the black sheep of AWS for auth (it's v4 signature is also different because it must support large data uploads).
[~mcrawford], Any luck with the setup where console points to UFS load balancer?

[~dkavanagh] I have not been able to get the latest console, or even the one that worked before, working on my latest rebuild done Friday. I'll be doing another one this morning. I sent you an email Friday on this, but no response yet. Can I ping you later today to debug this. I need the console to come up before I can verify this bug is fixed.
I'll go check my inbox. I was off last week and must have missed that.

I've just tested using nginx on the same host as the console, but different than the host running the UFS. The link presented on the object detail page works in this case. 
I've setup nginx on 1 host and the console on another. The S3 links still work since they point to the public-facing UFS endpoint.
[~mcrawford], I've done some testing as noted above and feel like things are working as intended. I'm looking to close this ticket and wondered if you were still experiencing problems?
